entry.title: Clarence Thomas Corruption Scandal Gets Worse
entry.content:
Joshua Kaplan, Justin Elliott, and Alex Mierjeski, reporting for ProPublica:

In 2008, Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas decided to send his teenage grandnephew to Hidden Lake Academy, a private boarding school in the foothills of northern Georgia. The boy, Mark Martin, was far from home. For the previous decade, he had lived with the justice and his wife in the suburbs of Washington, D.C. Thomas had taken legal custody of Martin when he was 6 years old and had recently told an interviewer he was ‚Äúraising him as a son.‚Äù

Tuition at the boarding school ran more than $6,000 a month. But Thomas did not cover the bill. A bank statement for the school from July 2009, buried in unrelated court filings, shows the source of Martin‚Äôs tuition payment for that month: the company of billionaire real estate magnate Harlan Crow. [‚Ä¶]

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be having secret financial arrangements,‚Äù said Mark W. Bennett, a retired federal judge appointed by President Bill Clinton. Bennett said he was friendly with Thomas and declined to comment for the record about the specifics of Thomas‚Äô actions. But he said that when he was on the bench, he wouldn‚Äôt let his lawyer friends buy him lunch. [‚Ä¶]

‚ÄúThis is way outside the norm. This is way in excess of anything I‚Äôve seen,‚Äù said Richard Painter, former chief White House ethics lawyer for President George W. Bush, referring to the cascade of gifts over the years.

Painter said that when he was at the White House, an official who‚Äôd taken what Thomas had would have been fired: ‚ÄúThis amount of undisclosed gifts? You‚Äôd want to get them out of the government.‚Äù

Just breathtaking corruption. And Thomas‚Äôs response is basically, ‚ÄúFuck you.‚Äù

entry.title: Ford CEO Jim Farley Seems Very Happy That GM Is Dropping CarPlay
entry.content:
Great 3-minute clip from Joanna Stern‚Äôs interview with Ford CEO Jim Farley at the WSJ‚Äôs Future of Everything Festival. She asks him about GM‚Äôs plan to drop CarPlay from their future EVs, and Farley starts by saying ‚ÄúYeah, how about that?‚Äù and laughing.

Farley says, ‚ÄúThe interior has to be really well done. But in terms of content? We kind of lost that battle 10 years ago. So get real with it, because you‚Äôre not going to make a ton of money on content inside the vehicle. It‚Äôs going to be safety/security, partial autonomy, and productivity in our eyes. [...] 70 percent of our Ford customers in the U.S are Apple customers. Why would I go to an Apple customer and say ‚ÄòGood luck!‚Äô? That doesn‚Äôt seem customer centric.‚Äù

Farley and Ford have it exactly right. New car buyers, even from mainstream brands like Ford, are overwhelmingly iPhone users‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâexactly as Apple bragged at WWDC last June, and what iPhone users want in their cars is CarPlay. If anything, Farley is being kind to GM and GM CEO Mary Barra when he says their message to iPhone users is ‚ÄúGood luck‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit‚Äôs really more like ‚ÄúFuck you.‚Äù And again, the most telling part of the whole exchange is the way Farley laughs at the start. It‚Äôs enough to make you think Mary Barra is a mole from Ford, planted to steer would-be Chevy buyers into Ford dealerships.

If you‚Äôre asking how it can be that 70 percent of Ford‚Äôs customers are iPhone users when the iPhone has maybe just over 50 percent market share in the U.S., the key is new car buyers. The Android masses are buying used cars, either because they don‚Äôt have the budget for a new car or because they don‚Äôt care about buying nice things (or both). So even a non-luxury brand like Ford has an overwhelming majority of customers with iPhones.

entry.summary: The decline of Windows, and slow and steady rise of Safari and the Mac.
entry.content:
Joshua Benton on Twitter, linking to Statcounter‚Äôs U.S. browser share data for March:

For the first time ever, Safari has more than 20% of desktop browser share in the U.S.

Since last June, Chrome is down 6% (61.35% to 55.28%), while Safari is up by a similar amount (15.58% to 22.3%).

Seems driven entirely by increased Mac market share. Over the same span, Windows is down 14% (67.57% to 53.43%) and macOS is up 6% (24.27% to 31.34%). ChromeOS went from 3.75% to 8.47% (though the school year makes that comp a bit unfair).

Statcounter‚Äôs latest global numbers:

  • Chrome: 66.1%
  • Safari: 11.9%
  • Edge: 11%
  • Firefox: 5.7%
  • Opera: 3.1%

Looking at the global chart, Chrome seems to be holding steady in the desktop market over the last year, but Safari does show an uptick from about 9.5 to just under 11 percent. As Benton points out, the most striking thing in Statcounter‚Äôs report is the decline in Windows‚Äôs desktop OS share over the last year, both globally and in the U.S. I suspect Windows is losing share to mobile browsing just as much or more so than it is to MacOS and ChromeOS. Back when Windows had over 90 percent market share, a huge chunk of that was people who didn‚Äôt really choose a Windows PC because of Windows, but who just wanted a ‚Äúcomputer‚Äù. They took the default, and the default computer ran Windows.

Nowadays, Windows still gets most of the default desktop market (although it seem ChromeOS continues to eat into that, especially in K-12 education). But for more and more people, their default ‚Äúcomputer‚Äù is their phone. They might have a PC, but they use it less and less.

Which brings me to another real eye-opener: Statcounter‚Äôs OS market share numbers‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâacross all devices, desktop and mobile‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâfrom 2009 until now.

Globally:

United States:

Globally, Windows was surpassed by Android back in 2017. The decline in Windows‚Äôs dominance has been precipitous: in 2009 Statcounter pegged its share at 95 percent; today it‚Äôs 28 percent. In the U.S., Windows is effectively neck-and-neck with iOS, each hovering around 30 percent for the last few years. It doesn‚Äôt seem outlandish to project that Mac and iOS, combined, might soon surpass Windows and Android combined in Statcounter‚Äôs share numbers for the U.S.

The Mac, on the other hand, is clearly seeing impressive market share growth. We all kind of knew this was true from the Mac revenue numbers Apple reports each quarter, but Statcounter‚Äôs data backs up Apple‚Äôs claims that the Mac continues to gain new users. And that in turn leads to more desktop Safari users‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeven though recent switchers strike me as among the most likely Mac users to use Chrome, which they‚Äôre likely familiar with. But if desktop Safari usage share is growing, it must mean Mac usage is growing.

The rise of iOS and Android as humanity‚Äôs primary computing platforms has obliterated Windows‚Äôs decades-long hegemony. To be fair, when your usage share was at one time 95 percent of all web browsing, there‚Äôs nowhere to go but down. But today, Windows is just one of four major platforms‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand is the only one of the four that is in obvious decline, both in usage and relevance. The Mac, on the other hand, has seemingly been bolstered by the rise of the iPhone. We talked a lot about the ‚Äúhalo effect‚Äù of the iPod on Mac sales in the mid-2000s, but it‚Äôs more true today with the iPhone and iPad. Mac unit sales are up and its share of desktop computing is way up. People who don‚Äôt care about desktop computing are just using their phones and tablets for everything; people who do care are more likely than ever to be using a Mac.

One more nugget, just for kicks‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâU.S. and worldwide numbers for iOS and Android in the mobile market:

Android 40 69

It‚Äôs also worth noting on the charts above that in hindsight, it wasn‚Äôt clear that mobile browsing would surpass desktop browsing until 2013 or 2014‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâsix or seven years after the debut of the iPhone. That‚Äôs a timeframe worth keeping in mind for‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâoh, just to pick a random up-and-coming product category‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâAR/VR headsets. The iPhone did change everything, but it took a while to show it outside the enthusiast‚Äâ/‚Äâearly-adopter market.

entry.summary: This situation I ran into‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâseeing a promotion for a three-month Apple Arcade trial despite the fact that I pay for Apple One (which includes Arcade)‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâis a glitch that only happened for some people who, like me, have split Apple IDs: one for iTunes and another for iCloud.
entry.content:
Yours truly, two weeks ago:

For the last several weeks, I‚Äôve noticed an ad in Settings on my iPhone, in the iCloud section at the very top of the first screen: ‚ÄúApple Arcade Free for 3 Months‚Äù. The reason this is dumb is that I pay for a family account for Apple One, so we already have Apple Arcade. But here‚Äôs Apple badgering me to sign up for a 3-month free trial that I don‚Äôt need.

If I tap into that ad‚Äôs section in Settings it explains why they‚Äôre offering it: ‚ÄúServices Included With Purchase‚Äù. I‚Äôm not even sure what device I bought that earned me this offer, but it shouldn‚Äôt matter. Why are they showing me something I already pay for?

This prompted some give-and-take with, well, people familiar with the matter, and I have an answer to share. The problem I was running into was a bug that resulted from the fact I have split Apple ID accounts: one account for iTunes and App Store purchases, and a separate account for my Apple ID. Long story short:

  • I created my mac.com iCloud account back in January 2000, when Apple launched the service under the name iTools. That same service was soon renamed .Mac, then MobileMe (and Apple changed the domain name to me.com), then, finally, iCloud (and icloud.com).

  • When I signed up for my iTunes account when the iTunes Music Store launched back in April 2003, I used my primary @daringfireball.net address, not my @mac.com address. I don‚Äôt recall why I did this exactly, but I think that what I was thinking was something along the lines of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still not sure about this whole .Mac thing, but I‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôll have my daringfireball.net address forever.‚Äù

In hindsight, this was a mistake on my part. Everything is simpler if you only have one Apple ID that you use for both iCloud and iTunes/App Store purchases. The reason I never switched to using my mac.com iCloud account for everything, including purchases, is that there‚Äôs never been a way to migrate old purchases from a different account. And I‚Äôve bought a lot of music, movies, and apps over the years using my other account.1

Using split accounts has always been a bit weird, occasionally problematic and/or confusing‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut has mostly just worked out. It helps quite a bit that there are a lot of people working at Apple in the same situation. By the time the iPhone became a hit product, users new to the Apple ecosystem naturally used one address for everything. But split accounts are common from long-time Mac users, and there are a lot of long-time Mac users inside Apple.

This situation I ran into‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâseeing a promotion for a three-month Apple Arcade trial despite the fact that I pay for Apple One (which includes Arcade)‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâis just one of those glitches. Most Apple One subscribers don‚Äôt have split accounts, so they never saw the unnecessary promotion. And even amongst those who do have split accounts, they‚Äôd have to run into a certain set of circumstances to make it appear.2

So, it was a bug. And I am reliably informed that a fix is in the works that will appear in a near-future update to iOS.

  1. No joke, I‚Äôve purchased 744 movies (and counting) from iTunes over the last two decades. Money runs through my fingers like water. ↩︎

  2. One way that it‚Äôs confusing to have multiple Apple IDs is that it‚Äôs my iCloud account‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâmy mac.com address‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat serves as the primary account for family sharing with my wife and son. But it‚Äôs my other account‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâmy daringfireball.net address‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat has made all my iTunes and App Store purchases for 23 years. That includes making the purchase to subscribe to Apple One, even though Apple One includes features like additional iCloud storage space that apply to my iCloud account. So even though I have two accounts, one for iCloud and one for purchases, Apple‚Äôs back end is somehow capable of making it all work. They are two different accounts, but my iTunes account purchases can be shared through my iCloud account‚Äôs family sharing. It sounds confusing, I know. But for the last decade or so, it really has just worked and I haven‚Äôt had to think about it often, other than keeping two different passwords in my head. ↩︎Ô∏é

entry.summary: Anything that attempts to establish a post-phone beachhead has to do the things we love to do with our phones, or entertain us in new ways that make us forget about them. I don‚Äôt see how a laser projector on a chest badge does that.
entry.content:
Raymond Wong, reporting for Inverse, ‚ÄúWatch Humane‚Äôs Wearable AI Projector in Action‚Äù:

Humane, the top-secret tech startup founded by ex-Apple vets Imran Chaudhri and Bethany Bongiorno, just showed off the first demo for its projector-based wearable at a TED talk. Axios‚Äôs Ina Fried broke the news, and Inverse has seen a recording of the full TED talk given by Chaudhri.

Journalist Zarif Ali, who had tweeted out an image of Humane‚Äôs wearable projecting a phone call function onto Chaudhri‚Äôs palm, says the full TED talk video is not slated to become available until April 22.

So the full video should be out tomorrow, but in the meantime, Wong has pulled a bunch of clips. There‚Äôs some cool technology being shown, including on-the-fly translation from English to French using an AI-trained version of Chaudhri‚Äôs own voice, but what I fundamentally don‚Äôt get about Humane is their anti-phone slant. Chaudhri emphasizes that you don‚Äôt need a phone to use the unnamed Humane device, but if the device can receive and place phone calls, and has a network connection, must not their device itself be ... a phone? Just a phone in a different form factor.

Back in February when LeBron James broke the all-time NBA scoring title, Chaudhri retweeted someone comparing a photo of James‚Äôs record-breaking shot (with a seeming majority of the fans in the background holding their phones to capture the moment‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâalmost all of them iPhones, natch) with Michael Jordan‚Äôs iconic 1998 championship-winning shot against the Utah Jazz (with, of course, not a single fan with a phone in hand).1 Chaudhri‚Äôs comment on the comparison: ‚Äúwe all deserve better.‚Äù

The thought being, I surmise, that Chaudhri thinks something is wrong that so many of us turn to our phones to photograph or film major moments in our lives, rather than just enjoying them through our own senses. I get it to some degree. If I‚Äôd been at that Lakers game, my phone would‚Äôve been in my pocket at that moment, not just to absorb the actual game experience, but because I know that no photo I could take could possibly be as as good as those being taken by courtside professional sports photographers. But those thousands of fans who did have their phones out for that moment weren‚Äôt thinking ‚ÄúThis sucks, I wish I didn‚Äôt have to stare at my phone to capture this.‚Äù They were thinking ‚ÄúThis is awesome and I‚Äôm glad I can capture this.‚Äù

People take their own photos at major events not because they think those will be great photos, but because they‚Äôre proof that they were there. Selfies are the new autographs, and a shaky iPhone photo from the perspective of your own seat at the event is the new certificate of attendance.

We still don‚Äôt know much about Humane‚Äôs device, as Wong‚Äôs colleague at Inverse Ian Carlos Campbell notes in this follow-up piece. But everything we do know seems positioned around the notion of relieving us of the burden of being tethered to our iPhones all day every day. The fundamental flaw in Humane‚Äôs entire premise, as I see it, is that people don‚Äôt feel burdened by their phones. People love them‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâespecially iPhone owners. And those who are ambivalent or even downright antipathetic toward their phones surely aren‚Äôt the sort of people who are interested in a newfangled laser-projecting AI-driven chest-badge computer.

I wrote about this all the way back in 2010, in the era of the iPhone 4, when Microsoft debuted a high-budget ad campaign for their answer to the iPhone, Windows Phone 7. The ads were very entertaining‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâparticularly this one‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut the whole premise was fundamentally flawed. Microsoft‚Äôs message was that if you switched to Windows Phone you wouldn‚Äôt need to stare at your phone all the time. The problem is that people stare at their phones all the time not because they have to but because they want to.

‚ÄúFinally, you can replace this thing that you despise‚Äù is a powerful marketing message. ‚ÄúFinally, you can replace this thing that you love‚Äù is not.

So far, it feels like Humane‚Äôs entire premise is founded on that same mistake: building a new device intended to replace our phones, without that new device being able to do any of the dozens of things we love to do on our phones that require a display. Apple Watch and AirPods thrive because they‚Äôre satellites to our iPhones, not ostensible replacements. Our iPhones aren‚Äôt a burden‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthey‚Äôre a pleasure. I‚Äôm not arguing there are no downsides to our collective mass addiction to our phones. There‚Äôs undeniably a nostalgic appeal to many aspects of the pre-iPhone age. But the notion of even a single trip to the grocery store without a phone to provide (unlimited!) material to read or watch while I wait at the checkout line seems like veritable torture to me now. Anything that attempts to establish a post-phone beachhead has to do the things we love to do with our phones, or entertain us in new ways that make us forget about them. I don‚Äôt see how a laser projector on a chest badge does that.

  1. Not only are there no fans with cell phones in hand in the Jordan photo, there are none with any sort of camera in hand. Cell phone cameras were uncommon in 1998, but regular cameras were not. But before the iPhone age, when such policies became untenable, events like concerts and indoor sporting events banned cameras. Same thing with casinos. And even if the rules didn‚Äôt prohibit cameras, people just didn‚Äôt have the habit of taking their own photographs. Today we don‚Äôt just take photos with our phones instead of with standalone cameras‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwe take thousands of photos every year that we never would have taken in the first place, because we wouldn‚Äôt have had a camera with us. The best camera really is the one you have with you. ↩︎

entry.title: ‚ÄòArcade Game Typography‚Äô by Toshi Omagari
entry.content:
Read-Only Memory, video game book publishers extraordinaire:

The first book of its kind‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa definitive and beautifully designed survey of ‚Äô70s, ‚Äô80s and early ‚Äô90s arcade game pixel typography. Exhaustively researched by author Toshi Omagari (a celebrated typeface designer at Monotype UK) Arcade Game Typography gathers together 250 pixel typefaces, all carefully chosen, extracted, redrawn and categorised by style, and each with an accompanying commentary by Omagari. entry.summary: Promotions for services I might want? Maybe, but Apple should be extremely conservative about presenting them‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâespecially in push notifications. Promotions for services I already pay for? That shouldn‚Äôt happen.
entry.content:
Steve Streza, all the way back in February 2020 (innocent times, that month):

Over the years, Apple has built up a portfolio of services and add-ons that you pay for. Starting with AppleCare extended warranties and iCloud data subscriptions, they expanded to Apple Music a few years ago, only to dramatically ramp up their offerings last year with TV+, News+, Arcade, and Card. Their services business, taken as a whole, is quickly becoming massive; Apple reported $12.7 billion in Q1 2020 alone, nearly a sixth of its already gigantic quarterly revenue. [...]

If you don‚Äôt subscribe to these services, you‚Äôll be forced to look at these ads constantly, either in the apps you use or the push notifications they have turned on by default. The pervasiveness of ads in iOS is a topic largely unexplored, perhaps due to these services having a lot of adoption among the early adopter crowd that tends to discuss Apple and their design. This isn‚Äôt a value call on the services themselves, but a look at how aggressively Apple pushes you to pay for them, and how that growth-hack-style design comes at the expense of the user experience. In this post, I‚Äôll break down all of the places in iOS that I‚Äôve found that have Apple-manufactured ads. You can replicate these results yourself by doing a factory reset of an iPhone (backup first!), installing iOS 13, and signing up for a new iCloud account.

Streza‚Äôs post emphasizes the new-user experience, and he‚Äôs right that longtime users (like you, dear reader, probably) don‚Äôt see a lot of this. But I do, because when reviewing new devices or new OS releases, I‚Äôll sometimes set up as new (and use a spare Apple ID dedicated to testing) to see the factory-fresh Cupertino default experience. Is it too much advertising? I don‚Äôt know‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut it‚Äôs a lot. One thing that‚Äôs clear is that Apple sees Music and TV as Apple-service properties. Yes, you can use them for listening to your own music and watching your own video files, but first and foremost these are client apps to Apple‚Äôs Music and TV+ services. These are not the iTunes and Video apps of yore.

But what got me thinking about this issue this week is the dumbest adware in iOS I‚Äôve seen. For the last several weeks, I‚Äôve noticed an ad in Settings on my iPhone, in the iCloud section at the very top of the first screen: ‚ÄúApple Arcade Free for 3 Months‚Äù. The reason this is dumb is that I pay for a family account for Apple One, so we already have Apple Arcade. But here‚Äôs Apple badgering me to sign up for a 3-month free trial that I don‚Äôt need.

If I tap into that ad‚Äôs section in Settings it explains why they‚Äôre offering it: ‚ÄúServices Included With Purchase‚Äù. I‚Äôm not even sure what device I bought that earned me this offer, but it shouldn‚Äôt matter. Why are they showing me something I already pay for?

To be clear, I was able to make this ad go away by tapping ‚ÄúNot Now‚Äù on the offer screen in Settings. (I waited for weeks before doing so to see if it would go away on its own.) And I‚Äôm not blankly opposed to using this top-of-the-first-screen space in Settings to show offers for Apple‚Äôs services or AppleCare warranty coverage. But they ought to be presented conservatively, and with surgical precision. Apple is doing users a favor if they‚Äôre reminding them of offers‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâlike three free months of Apple Arcade‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthat they‚Äôve already qualified for with a hardware purchase. But it‚Äôs annoying and confusing that it‚Äôs the very app where I manage my Apple One subscription that‚Äôs suggesting I sign up for a service included in Apple One.

We‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâincluding Apple itself and Tim Cook personally‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâdecry the invasiveness of the surveillance advertising complex, by which they develop profiles of us so accurate that the ads they deliver are so on-point to our recent interests that millions of people falsely believe their devices are somehow surreptitiously listening to their real-world conversations. This stupid Apple Arcade prompt in Settings is the opposite: I‚Äôm being shown it because Apple knows I recently bought a new device from them, but somehow doesn‚Äôt know that I already pay them for a subscription that includes Arcade. How can they be so contextually unaware?

Promotions for services I might want? Maybe, but Apple should be extremely conservative about presenting them‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâespecially in push notifications. Promotions for services I already pay for? That shouldn‚Äôt happen.

Postscript, two weeks later: This bug was triggered by the fact that I‚Äôm an edge case, with separate Apple IDs for iCloud and for iTunes/App Store purchases.

entry.title: WhatsApp, Signal, and Other Secure Messaging Platforms Write Open Letter to the UK Government Defending End-to-End Encryption
entry.content:
From an open letter signed by the leaders of WhatsApp, Signal, Viber, and a few other secure services:

Proponents say that they appreciate the importance of encryption and privacy while also claiming that it‚Äôs possible to surveil everyone‚Äôs messages without undermining end-to-end encryption. The truth is that this is not possible.

We aren‚Äôt the only ones who share concerns about the UK Bill. The United Nations has warned that the UK Government‚Äôs efforts to impose backdoor requirements constitute ‚Äúa paradigm shift that raises a host of serious problems with potentially dire consequences‚Äù. Even the UK Government itself has acknowledged the privacy risks that the text of the Bill poses, but has said its ‚Äúintention‚Äù isn‚Äôt for the Bill to be interpreted this way.

Global providers of end-to-end encrypted products and services cannot weaken the security of their products and services to suit individual governments. There cannot be a ‚ÄúBritish internet,‚Äù or a version of end-to-end encryption that is specific to the UK.

The UK Government must urgently rethink the Bill, revising it to encourage companies to offer more privacy and security to its residents, not less. Weakening encryption, undermining privacy, and introducing the mass surveillance of people‚Äôs private communications is not the way forward.

I‚Äôm glad to see these companies defending end-to-end encryption, but this letter dances around the repercussions of this proposed legislation in the U.K. What they mean in the third paragraph quoted above is that if the legislation passes, people in the U.K. won‚Äôt be able to use WhatsApp or Signal or any other end-to-end encrypted service. Apple isn‚Äôt a signatory of the letter, but I think iMessage would be banned too.

Some reports are portraying this as though these services would begrudgingly comply if the law passes, but they can‚Äôt. End-to-end encryption is inherent to the protocols. If end-to-end encrypted messaging is banned in the U.K., it won‚Äôt mean that WhatsApp, Signal, et al will somehow switch to insecure protocols in order to comply‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit will mean that people in the U.K. can‚Äôt use these apps.

It‚Äôs tough, messaging-wise, because coming right out and saying that sounds like these companies won‚Äôt comply, by choice. Laypeople seemingly can‚Äôt be made to understand that a ‚Äúgood-guys-only back door‚Äù is cryptographically impossible. But that‚Äôs the truth. WhatsApp is incredibly popular in the U.K.‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe message should not be that U.K. lawmakers are trying to weaken WhatsApp‚Äôs encryption, but rather that U.K. lawmakers are going to make WhatsApp illegal.

entry.title: App of the Day: Glucomate
entry.content:
New app from developer Zach Simone‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâan iPhone and Apple Watch app for blood glucose recording, tracking, and monitoring. I don‚Äôt have diabetes, but I know many people who do or have loved ones who do, and it seems hard to overstate how important blood glucose monitoring is. Simone, on his blog:

For over 20 years, I‚Äôve had to monitor my blood glucose every single day. The way in which I monitor it has changed a bit over the years, but the need to stay on top of the readings hasn‚Äôt. [...]

A [continuous glucose monitor] generates a lot of data, and the one I use even writes that data to HealthKit (though admittedly with a 3-hour delay). Real-time information is only available via the manufacturers app, unless you‚Äôre willing to jump through many hoops. No matter, there‚Äôs still a huge amount of data being collected. And it starts to build up. But surely all of this data is good for something. What can we do with it?

That‚Äôs where Glucomate comes in. It‚Äôs an app for people who record, track, and monitor their blood glucose and use HealthKit to do it. Glucomate is the app that finally does something with all that data. You can analyse recent readings, spot trends, or go back to any date and view its history. It does all this while trying to look as good as possible. A notable feature is the ability to customise each of the tabs by reordering the displayed data. You can even choose to hide the data that isn‚Äôt relevant to you.

The best apps, almost invariably, come from developers scratching their own itches. It looks to me like Simone has made a terrifically practical tool for anyone monitoring their blood glucose levels. If you have diabetes or know someone who does, Glucomate seems worth a look.

(There are rumors that future Apple Watch models might integrate sensors that read blood glucose levels continuously and non-invasively (read: without puncturing your skin), but that‚Äôs just a rumor, and even if it comes to pass, diabetics will still need ways to monitor their trends.)

entry.summary: HBO‚Äôs new slogan might as well be ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not TV. It‚Äôs a tab somewhere in the Max app.‚Äù
entry.content:
Warner Bros. Discovery:

Warner Bros. Discovery today introduced Max, its enhanced streaming service, which will launch in the U.S. on May 23. Max is the destination for HBO Originals, Warner Bros. films, Max Originals, the DC universe, the Wizarding World of Harry Potter, an expansive offering of kids content, and best-in-class programming across food, home, reality, lifestyle and documentaries from leading brands like HGTV, Food Network, Discovery Channel, TLC, ID and more. Max will stand out amongst streamers by uniquely combining unrivaled breadth and superior quality with iconic franchises and strong product experience, all for great value.

I would argue the opposite: that by cramming their entire disparate gamut of brands into a single service, none of them stand out, and the Max brand stands for nothing.1

Max will offer three pricing options, giving subscribers the choice to select which plan best fits the needs of their household.

  • Max Ad-Lite‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ$9.99/month or $99.99/year
    2 concurrent streams, 1080p resolution, no offline downloads, 5.1 surround sound quality
  • Max Ad Free‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ$15.99/month or $149.99/year
    2 concurrent streams, 1080 resolution, 30 offline downloads, 5.1 surround sound quality
  • Max Ultimate Ad Free‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâ$19.99/month or $199.99/year
    4 concurrent streams, up to 4K UHD resolution, 100 offline downloads, Dolby Atmos sound quality

These prices are pretty much the same as Netflix‚Äôs, except that Netflix‚Äôs ‚Äúbasic with ads‚Äù tier (it‚Äôs adorable that Max is calling theirs ‚Äúad-lite‚Äù) is $7/month and, criminally, still limited to 720p resolution. Disney+ currently offers two plans: $8/month with ads, or $11/month without (and with offline downloads). Disney+ also offers bundles with Hulu and ESPN+: $13/month with ads, $20/month without. Apple TV+‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwith a growing but admittedly boutique-sized library compared to Max, Netflix, and Disney/Hulu‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâis $7/month, and has no tier with ads.

When this ‚ÄúMax‚Äù name truncation was first rumored in December, I wrote:

Not the worst name they could go with. The mistake with ‚ÄúHBO Max‚Äù was muddying the premium HBO brand with the ‚Äúanything and everything‚Äù content of a unified app for everything this enormous content factory conglomerate puts online. My big question is what happens to HBO content. Is it stuck in a tab inside the ‚ÄúMax‚Äù app, or will there be a standalone ‚ÄúHBO‚Äù app too?

Looks like HBO is now just a brand inside the Max service. They‚Äôre ceding the ‚Äúeverything you get on this service is premium content, and there are no ads‚Äù ground to Apple TV+. HBO is still HBO on cable, but as the world inexorably moves to an all-streaming future, this feels like ‚Äúcorporate synergy‚Äù run amok. The non-HBO content in HBO Max already diluted the brand; now they‚Äôre putting even more non-premium content (all the Discovery crap) into the same app. (Today‚Äôs New York Times headline says it all: ‚Äú‚ÄòSuccession‚Äô and ‚ÄòDr. Pimple Popper‚Äô Together in New Warner Streaming App‚Äù.)

Disney set the example Warner Bros. Discovery should have followed, with Disney+ and Hulu as separate apps, but priced together in a bundle. Disney isn‚Äôt relegating Disney+ content into a mere tab in the Hulu app, nor are they allowing Hulu‚Äôs content to dilute the prestigious Disney brand in the Disney+ app.

They obviously think they‚Äôve being clever with the Max logotype having a dot inside the ‚Äúa‚Äù, evoking the ‚Äúo‚Äù in HBO‚Äôs, but I find it just sad‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe bastardization of an iconic mark. Either Max stands on its own, independent of HBO, or HBO should be the brand for HBO content.

HBO‚Äôs old slogan was ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not TV. It‚Äôs HBO‚Äù. That slogan captured HBO‚Äôs prestige: unedited major motion pictures, best-of-breed original content, all without commercial interruptions. HBO‚Äôs new slogan might as well be ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not TV. It‚Äôs a tab somewhere in the Max app.‚Äù

  1. The nomenclatural trend du jour for subscription services is to take your company‚Äôs existing well-known brand and tack on a suffix like plus, max, or one. Hence: Disney+, ESPN+, Paramount+, Apple TV+, Apple One, Google One‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeven Canal+ in France. I think that‚Äôs what Warner was going for with the ‚ÄúMax‚Äù in HBO Max. So in some sense going with just plain ‚ÄúMax‚Äù makes no more branding sense than if Disney+ or Paramount+ had been named just ‚ÄúPlus‚Äù. But for those of you my age or older, Max also brings to mind Cinemax‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâWarner‚Äôs longtime cable-pay-channel sibling to HBO. Premium and commercial-free, like HBO, but clearly not as premium. HBO is Joe DiMaggio; Cinemax is Dom DiMaggio. HBO is the home of hall-of-fame groundbreaking original series like The Sopranos, The Wire, The Larry Sanders Show, Curb Your Enthusiasm, Game of Thrones, and Succession. Cinemax is the home of ... checks notes ... Banshee, The Knick, Warrior, and Mike Judge Presents: Tales from the Tour Bus. Cinemax‚Äôs biggest claim to fame from my teenage years is that after a certain hour, they showed movies that earned them the nickname ‚ÄúSkinemax‚Äù. (Sleepovers were always preferably held at the homes of Cinemax subscribers.)

    No matter what Warner Bros. Discovery intends ‚ÄúMax‚Äù to mean, it feels damn stupid to lean even vaguely on Cinemax, and not at all on HBO, as a brand name. ↩︎

entry.summary: In many ways our phones are our new digital hubs, and CarPlay exemplifies that role.
entry.content:
Jason Snell, writing at Six Colors, ‚ÄúGeneral Motors Hates Your iPhone‚Äù:

I get the impulse to want to control everything that happens in your car, if you‚Äôre an automaker. But given the fact that the smartphone is everyone‚Äôs real ride-or-die, the best choice is to integrate tightly with the supercomputer we all keep in our pockets, not to say ‚Äúlet them eat Bluetooth‚Äù and be happy degrading the customer experience in the interest of control and incremental revenue. [...]

Will GM‚Äôs competitors follow its lead, relieved that the world is finally starting to trend away from bring-your-own-device support in cars? Or will they consider CarPlay a competitive advantage that will allow them to market their own vehicles against GM‚Äôs? I sure hope it‚Äôs the latter, because we‚Äôre never going to give up our smartphones‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand if our cars don‚Äôt talk to them properly, our in-car experiences will always be second-rate.

One thought I had regarding this decision by GM is that it‚Äôs a bit like selling ‚Äúsmart‚Äù TV sets that don‚Äôt support HDMI input. You get the TV maker‚Äôs interface for using apps, games, and streaming services, with no choice to plug in a third-party device like an Apple TV, Chromecast stick, or Roku. I don‚Äôt know of any TV sets like that, but HomePods are sort of like that as speakers. HomePods have no traditional line-in for audio‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhatever sound comes out of your HomePods, it comes through Apple‚Äôs own software stack. GM is more like a traditional speaker company. It‚Äôd be really weird if, say, Bose sold a set of smart speakers that didn‚Äôt support line-in, because unlike Apple, Bose isn‚Äôt a leading software platform company.

Tesla is seemingly thriving while going its own way software-wise. Rivian is following Tesla‚Äôs lead, and can‚Äôt manufacture their vehicles fast enough to keep up with demand. But both of those companies have roots in Silicon Valley, not Detroit. Both Tesla and Rivian seem more like Apple than they do General Motors.

Marques Brownlee had Rivian CEO R.J. Scaringe as his guest on his Waveform podcast this week (recorded in the cabin of a Rivian R1S), and asked him about Rivian‚Äôs decision not to support CarPlay or Android Auto. Scaringe‚Äôs answer (11m:49s) was good:

‚ÄúI mean a lot of the things we do, like whether it‚Äôs music or mapping, we have to make sure we integrate in with the best-in-class platforms. But by controlling the system it just allows us to be the ... arbiter, the head chef, in terms of the experience that you get, versus handing over control of what we think is one of the most important parts of the experience.‚Äù

Rivian sees itself as much as a software company as a hardware one. That‚Äôs an ambitious gamble, to be sure, but Scaringe‚Äôs comments clearly show that Rivian understands the stakes, and are doing this to put the overall driving/ownership experience first.1

The system that runs the onboard computer is a major factor in car-buying decisions today, and it‚Äôs only increasing in importance with each passing year. If GM, in collaboration with Google, creates their own custom platform that makes people as happy as Tesla‚Äôs and Rivian‚Äôs do, well, OK. But I have no faith in GM or Google to pull that off. I personally know several Tesla owners whose number one complaint is that Teslas don‚Äôt support CarPlay, and I know other people who have chosen cars other than Teslas solely for that reason. A lot of Tesla owners and would-be owners wish Tesla supported CarPlay‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand I would wager heavily that GM never delivers a system that‚Äôs as good as Tesla‚Äôs, let alone CarPlay.

And the fact that GM is doing this in collaboration with Google already puts them in different territory than Tesla or Rivian, who‚Äôve created their own entire software stacks. If GM is only going to support its own automotive software system, they ought to be willing and able to do the entire thing themselves, with confidence that they‚Äôll provide a best-in-class experience for owners. Otherwise this seems like a data grab by Google‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâcollecting location, search, and music/podcast listening data from every driver of every vehicle GM eventually sells with this system‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand a SaaS revenue grab by GM. From the Reuters report that broke this news:

Buyers of GM EVs with the new systems will get access to Google Maps and Google Assistant, a voice command system, at no extra cost for eight years, GM said. GM said the future infotainment systems will offer applications such as Spotify‚Äôs music service, Audible and other services that many drivers now access via smartphones.

‚ÄúWe do believe there are subscription revenue opportunities for us,‚Äù Kummer said. GM Chief Executive Mary Barra is aiming for $20 billion to $25 billion in annual revenue from subscriptions by 2030.

This sounds like a decision motivated entirely by a desire to generate a significant new services revenue stream, and not at all motivated by a desire to create the best possible driving/passenger experience.

One influential group that knows the importance of CarPlay integration are car dealers. Say what you want about car salespeople, they know exactly what motivates buying decisions. I suspect GM corporate is getting an earful from GM dealers regarding this decision. I don‚Äôt know if GM is planning to share that future subscription revenue with dealers, but they won‚Äôt get a penny from every sale lost to a rival whose cars do support CarPlay.2

20 years ago Apple presented the Mac as the ideal ‚Äúdigital hub‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe connection between all of one‚Äôs disparate devices, from MP3 players to cameras. A decade later, Apple went all-in on iCloud, and cloud computing in general, as the new hub. But in many ways our phones are our new digital hubs. They serve a very different role from what Macs and PCs did 20 years ago. Rather than serve as a hub for hardware peripherals, our phones serve as our primary hub for software services and apps. CarPlay exemplifies that role.

  1. I wonder how much of a factor it is that Apple has spent the last decade not-so-secretly working on creating its own line of cars? There‚Äôs no way GM would ever integrate a software system from, say, Ford or Honda. But so why integrate CarPlay, which comes from a company that seemingly wants to compete with existing automakers? Apple‚Äôs own car ambitions make CarPlay integration, to some extent, seem like a wolf in sheep‚Äôs clothing. ↩︎Ô∏é

  2. I wonder too about car rental fleets. I‚Äôd be furious today if I rented a car that didn‚Äôt support CarPlay. I might be willing to learn a new system in a new car I bought, but when I rent a car, I just want to connect my iPhone and get the navigation, music, and podcast experience I already know. ↩︎
